metadata.case_name: Defendant in Suit No. 134 of 1956 (Appellant) v. Rup Chand Jain (since deceased) represented by heirs (Respondents)

facts.text: Phula Kuer filed Small Cause Suit No. 1023 of 1951 against appellant to recover Rs. 750 as her share of partnership profits at Rs. 150 per month.
Appellant filed Suit No. 20 of 1953 against Phula Kuer for fixation of fair rent of premises owned by her.
Phula Kuer died on July 13, 1953.

Rup Chand Jain, as next reversioner of Phula Kuer, filed Suit No. 134 of 1956 on May 19, 1956, claiming Rs. 4,200 as unpaid profits from October 14, 1950, rent at Rs. 150 per month, and eviction; total Rs. 9,390.
All three suits transferred to Court of Second Civil Judge, Kanpur on August 4, 1956, and consolidated for joint hearing on August 23, 1956, with evidence in Suit 134 treated as evidence in others.
Appellant filed written statement in Suit 134 on October 10, 1956, denying partnership, asserting tenancy, and that statutory conditions for eviction not satisfied.
Issues settled on February 28, 1958.
On May 24, 1958, joint application by parties for two months to settle; refused as Suit 20/1953 was old.
On May 28, 1958, adjourned to May 29, 1958, with order: 'If no compromise is filed the case would be taken up for final hearing.'

On May 29, 1958, appellant absent, counsel reported no instructions; court proceeded ex parte in Suits 134/1956 and 1023/1951, examined plaintiff's witness Mohindra Kumar, reserved judgment; Suit 20/1953 dismissed for plaintiff's absence.
On May 31, 1958, appellant filed applications in all three suits to set aside ex parte orders/dismissal, alleging heat-stroke prevented attendance on May 29 after compromise talks.
Plaintiff filed counter-affidavit disputing illness.
On August 23, 1958, Civil Judge held appellant's illness story false, refused to set aside dismissal in Suit 20/1953, directed judgments in other suits on August 25.
Appellant filed revision in Allahabad High Court against order in Suit 134; stayed judgment delivery.
High Court dismissed revision on September 4, 1958, noting no decree yet passed, appellant could participate from current stage per Sangram Singh; no interference.
On September 8, 1958 (inferred within 4 days), appellant applied per High Court direction to lead evidence.
On September 25, 1958, Civil Judge dismissed applications as hearing over, appellant only entitled to hear judgment; delivered ex parte decrees in Suits 134 and 1023.
Appellant filed application under O. IX r.13 to set aside ex parte decree in Suit 134, same ground of illness.
Civil Judge dismissed O.IX r.13 app on res judicata from earlier O.IX r.7 finding.
High Court upheld dismissal on res judicata.
Rup Chand Jain died pending High Court appeal; heirs brought on record.

legal_issues.text: Whether the finding in the earlier application under O. IX r.7 that there was no good cause for non-appearance operates as res judicata barring re-inquiry under O. IX r.13.
Whether O. IX r.7 was applicable after hearing concluded and judgment reserved, or was the court without jurisdiction.
Whether finding in restoration application under O. IX r.9 in Suit 20/1953 bars O. IX r.13 in Suit 134/1956 due to consolidation.
Whether the decree was ex parte under O. IX or on merits under O. XVII r.3.

petitioner_arguments.text: No res judicata between O. IX r.7 and r.13 proceedings as they are different stages; O. IX r.7 interlocutory and does not attain finality.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Satyadhyan Ghosal v. Deorajin Debi; Sangram Singh v. Election Tribunal; O. IX r.7, r.13 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: O. IX r.7 inapplicable as hearing completed on May 29, 1958, suit adjourned only for judgment under O. XX r.1, no 'adjournment of hearing'.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O. IX r.7, O. XX r.1 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: No difference between 'good cause' and 'sufficient cause' pressed seriously.

respondent_arguments.text: Finding of no sufficient cause in May 31, 1958 application under O. IX r.7 bars re-inquiry under O. IX r.13 by res judicata.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S. 11 CPC; principle of res judicata in same suit stages; Satyadhyan Ghosal

respondent_arguments.text: Finding in O. IX r.9 restoration in Suit 20/1953 bars due to joint trial.
Decree not ex parte but on merits under O. XVII r.3 as adjourned at defendant's instance.
Court has inherent power under S.151 even if O.IX r.7 inapplicable.

court_reasoning.text: Principle of res judicata applies to different stages of same suit but depends on nature of proceedings; O. IX r.7 is summary interlocutory for orderly conduct, no finality, no appeal, does not bar O. IX r.13.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interlocutory orders under O. IX r.7 do not decide merits or attain finality like decrees.

court_reasoning.text: O. IX r.7 applies only where suit adjourned for hearing; here hearing completed May 29, adjourned only for judgment pronouncement under O. XX r.1; no jurisdiction under O. IX r.7, so no res judicata.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No adjournment of hearing after completion; O. IX r.6 followed by r.13.

court_reasoning.text: No inherent power under S.151 as O.IX exhausts contingencies for non-appearance; no gap between hearing end and judgment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Code provides complete scheme; inherent power cannot override.

court_reasoning.text: Consolidation for joint hearing does not make applications in one suit apply to others; issues distinct (plaintiff vs defendant non-appearance).
Decree ex parte under O. IX, not O. XVII r.3; adjournment not solely at defendant's instance.

holdings.text: Decision under O. IX r.7 does not operate as res judicata for O. IX r.13 application.
O. IX r.7 inapplicable after hearing concluded; Civil Judge lacked jurisdiction on May 31 application.
No res judicata from O. IX r.9 in consolidated suit.
Decree is ex parte, O. IX r.13 remedy available.

precedents_cited.relevance: Explains O. IX r.6, r.7: no order to set aside 'ex parte order'; defendant can participate from stage joined without setting clock back.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satyadhyan Ghosal v. Sm. Deorajin Debi
precedents_cited.relevance: Res judicata applies between stages of same litigation but distinguishes interlocutory orders without finality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Kirpal Shukul v. Rup Kuari
precedents_cited.relevance: Res judicata where previous decision part of decree, not mere interlocutory.
O. IX r.7 rejection does not bar r.13 application on same ground.
Repelled res judicata plea between analogous provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs setting aside ex parte decrees/proceedings; scheme exhausts remedies for non-appearance; no res judicata between r.7 and r.13.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court and trial court orders dismissing O. IX r.13 application on res judicata, remanded to trial court for disposal on merits as O. IX r.7 was inapplicable post-hearing.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand of O. IX r.13 application for hearing on merits.

key_quotes.text: "The principle of res judicata applies also as between two stages in the same litigation to this extent that a court... having at an earlier stage decided a matter in one way will not allow the parties to re-agitate the matter again at a subsequent stage."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Satyadhyan Ghosal; sets scope but court qualifies for interlocutory O.IX r.7.

key_quotes.text: "If a party does appear on the day to which the hearing of the suit is adjourned, he cannot be stopped from participating in the proceedings simply because he did not appear on the first or some other hearing. But... he has no right to set back the hands of the clock."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Sangram Singh; explains O.IX r.7 effect.

key_quotes.text: "Where the Court has adjourned the hearing of the suit ex parte..." O.IX r.7 opening words assume hearing to occur; no application post-hearing completion.
key_quotes.speaker: court
